item.title: One Of The Biggest YouTubers In The World Asks Fans To Stop Paying Him
item.content:encoded:
Popular streamer Charles White Jr., aka Cr1TiKal/MoistCr1TiKaL, that long-haired dude who seems to be a pretty good person, has taken the unusual step of shutting off his YouTube memberships and Super Chats. Instead of prompting his viewers to throw money at the screen, he‚Äôs instead urging folks to donate to charity. ‚ÄúThere are so many better options for your money,‚Äù he said.

As first reported by VGC, White has posted a video announcing that he‚Äôs shut off user-donated monetization on his YouTube channel, and saying that he‚Äôd shut off Twitch subs as well if he could. ‚ÄúI would say toodle-oo, give it a strong slap on the ass, tell it good game and goodbye.‚Äù But apparently it‚Äôs harder than that. Still, he stressed that money spent on his stream could be put to better use:

There are so many good charities doing extremely good work that could be benefited greatly from your contribution. Like maybe you‚Äôd want to donate to a charity that‚Äôs doing extremely important work in Gaza. That would be a significantly better use of that money than donating it to me.

item.title: Finally, A Gaming Chair I Don‚Äôt Have To Be Embarrassed By
item.content:encoded:
Stuff for gamers tends to look‚Ä¶ridiculous. You‚Äôve got all these sharp angles, and don‚Äôt get me started on the constant need to shove RBG LEDs into friggin‚Äô everything. Well, in stark contrast to that trend,  Elgato, makers of the Stream Deck, various capture cards, and other kit for streaming setups, has a new chair that looks almost too normal. And for a decent chair that‚Äôll last you? It ain‚Äôt sitting at too terrible of a price.

As spotted by The Verge, Elgato‚Äôs new chair, the ‚ÄúEmbrace,‚Äù comes in at $500 bucks and will be shipping this holiday season. It comes with all the design elements that make gaming chairs decent to sit in. For hours. Without moving. Staring at the screen with little urge to get up beyond necessary biological impulses.

As Tom Warren at The Verge states, the Embrace seems to be going up against Herman Miller‚Äôs ‚ÄúEmbody‚Äù chair which, I‚Äôll be honest, has a touch more personality with its color options. I‚Äôm really into the white and purple theme. Elegant, not overbearing. But wow, that thing costs almost $2,000. I‚Äôm sure it‚Äôll save me back problems down the line, but if I‚Äôm spending that kinda money and it‚Äôs not for rent, it‚Äôs almost certainly for something completely irresponsible. Plus, do I want to be that girl who spent two grand on a chair?

I‚Äôve had the same rando-brand chair I bought on Amazon for like five years now. It cost $300, and has held up through my many fits of punching the arm rests while listening to Gojira or some other crazy shit. If I do decide upon the Embrace as my next gaming chair, I‚Äôll be sure to let you know if you can beat the hell out of it. And how comfy it is.

But seriously! Like even just a two-tone color option would have added at least some personality without making me feel like I need to hide it if I bring a guy over or something.

item.title: Oh No, Someone Added Jack Black‚Äôs Minecraft Steve To Sonic Racing: Crossworlds
item.content:encoded:
The crossover characters and tracks are my least favorite thing about Sonic Racing: Crossworlds, an otherwise excellent kart racer that didn‚Äôt need a bunch of licensed partnerships to stand out. That said, it doesn‚Äôt surprise me that the modding community has taken that concept and run with it. I do wish someone would add more Sonic characters, such as Agent Stone from the live-action movies, but it seems like modders have other ideas, like Jack Black‚Äôs Steve from the Minecraft movie. This is basically my worst nightmare.

Steve, as he exists in the Minecraft games, is already in Crossworlds as DLC, but now you can play as his obnoxious film counterpart. The ‚ÄúJack Black Steve Collection‚Äù mod on GameBanana comes courtesy of user BROCHONKY, who has added two skins for Jack Black‚Äôs character to Crossworlds. One is a photoscanned action figure that looks just like the actor, while the other is a stylized version of the character that uses Minecraft‚Äòs signature blocky style. As a bonus, the mod also includes the infamous Chicken Jockey as it appears in the original game.

The mod doesn‚Äôt just include skins, it also has voice lines and music from the movie. Black‚Äôs trademark hammed-up delivery followed him into Overworld, so the movie has several soundbites that became memes, such as when he announces the Chicken Jockey‚Äôs arrival and says ‚Äúflint and steel‚Äù while teaching the other characters to craft. All of this seems like the making of a troll character, but I also feel like hearing these voice lines repeatedly during races would rot your own brain, so you reap what you sow. 

Sega is apparently cool with character mods, so Steve will live to Chicken Jockey another day. The company recently banned cheaters who used mods to win races, but the company‚Äôs End User License Agreement explicitly encourages creative work like adding new characters to their games. If I see Jack Black Steve on the racetrack, I will be running him off a cliff expeditiously.

item.title: Battlefield 6 Shatters Over 700,000 Concurrents On Steam As Fans Fight Errors And Login Queues
item.content:encoded:
Battlefield 6 is out today and it‚Äôs already blowing up on Steam. The multiplayer military shooter is already well on its way to a million concurrents on Steam alone as fans race to witness the franchise‚Äôs revival after years of stumbles and collective disappointment. The record-breaking influx initially meant long queues but now some players are facing others issues, including a weird bug that tells them they need to buy and download a multiplayer mode they already own to start playing.

Currently in the top-five most played games on Steam, Battlefield is the only game in the top four that‚Äôs paid. A $70 price tag hasn‚Äôt stopped it from overtaking Valve‚Äôs Dota 2 and Counter-Strike 2, or the perennial chart-topping battle royale PUBG. Players logging on when the game went live around 11:00 a.m. ET on Friday were immediately greeted by absurd queue positions featuring hundreds of thousands of other players trying to get into the always-online game.

350,000 in the queue for Battlefield 6 already ü§Ø pic.twitter.com/O6tPcS7e7R

‚Äî Tyler James (@FreakyMusic_) October 10, 2025

Battlefield lead producer David Sirland previously seemed confident that the sequel would be prepared to welcome in the flood of day-one players following months of beta hype and promising feedback. DICE was quick to point out that login queues are part of trying to keep the ramp-up process ‚Äúsmooth and stable for everyone.‚Äù That didn‚Äôt stop fans from jabbing each other with screenshots of their positions on social media and the Battlefield subreddit. Long before anyone has a KDA to brag about in Battlefield 6, fans are turning to queue positions as high-score markers of elite status. Can anyone beat 458,400?

Bro‚Ä¶.
how doe i play the game now? pic.twitter.com/wMwXmmHGWm

‚Äî DjKr4m3r Gaming (@djkr4m3r) October 10, 2025

But other players have been facing a strange issue in which, even after getting into the game, they would be asked to install it. ‚ÄúRunning into an error with Battlefield 6 that states I need to install multiplayer, and it shows me all the files I need to install,‚Äù one wrote on X. ‚ÄúDoes anyone have any fixes? I‚Äôm afraid I‚Äôm going to have to queue again.‚Äù Someone else even tried deleting the game, reinstalling everything, and queuing again to try and get in. ‚ÄúIf it works, please tell me,‚Äù another player wrote back.

So far, EA has said it‚Äôs aware of the problem but hasn‚Äôt shared advice on how to address it. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre aware of an issue preventing players from accessing the game with some receiving an error stating they need to purchase DLC or similar,‚Äù it announced around noon on Friday. ‚ÄúStay tuned for further updates as the team investigates this issue.‚Äù

In the meantime, Battlefield 6 seems well on its way to living up to to the initial blitz of player interest some had been predicting. Data firm Ampere Analysis told The Game Business it was forecasting 1.7 million copies pre-ordered on Steam alone. If all of them login within the first 24 hours, the fall blockbuster will be well on its way to being Steam‚Äôs most-played game so far this month.

To break into the top 10 of all-time highest concurrent player counts, it‚Äôll need to beat Banana‚Äòs 917,000 record. The top spot is still held by PUBG at over 3.2 million players simultaneously. EA will probably be content with having already edged out its own free-to-play giant Apex Legends, though. No wonder Activision seems so worried about Call of Duty: Black Ops 7 this year. It‚Äôs the first time in six years it‚Äôs had to go head-to-head with a Battlefield that had a single-player campaign, even if this one has left many critics overwhelmed.

Update 10/10/2025 3:04 p.m. ET: EA says it thinks it‚Äôs discovered the cause of the installation error some players are getting and will have a fix ready soon.
